title: MTM Waitlist - Core Questions (All Roles)
subtitle: Current State: Using tablesready.com â†’ Building Custom Solution
instructions: Keep answers simple. Tell us what works with tablesready.com and what doesn't. These are ideas, not final decisions.

questions.question: Your Name
questions.description: Who is completing this questionnaire?

questions.question: Your Department
questions.description: Which department do you work in?

questions.question: How Should People Log In?
questions.description: All operator computers are shared workstations.
questions.whyMatters: This choice affects setup cost and support needs (like password resets). Windows/AD means no passwords to manage, but needs the right network setup.
questions.example: If floor PCs are shared kiosks without AD, we'll need username/password. If supervisors use office PCs with Windows login, that could work automatically.
questions.note: Consider that operator computers are ALL shared - multiple people use the same machine.
options: Username and password (type it in each time)
Hybrid (Windows where it works, username/password as backup)
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: Can One Person Have Multiple Roles?
questions.description: Can someone be assigned multiple roles at once (like both Material Handler and Material Handler Lead)?
questions.whyMatters: If people can have multiple roles, it changes what screens they see and what they can do.
questions.example: A Production Lead who also runs a press during slow times might need both the Lead dashboard and the Operator screens.
options: Yes - people can have multiple roles
No - one role per person only
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: What Information Is Required to Submit a Request?
questions.description: Check all fields that MUST be filled out before someone can submit a request.
questions.whyMatters: Missing info means handlers have to hunt for details before they start. But too many required fields slow down creating requests.
questions.example: Without a zone, the handler doesn't know where to go. Without a work order, the request might not tie to the right job.

options.label: Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: Can Requests Be Changed After Assignment?
questions.description: After a request is assigned to someone, can the requester still edit or cancel it?
questions.whyMatters: Blocking changes means handlers know the request won't shift on them. Allowing changes gives flexibility for quick fixes but might mean redoing work.
questions.example: An operator submits a request for coils, then realizes they typed the wrong part number after a handler already accepted it. Can they fix it?
options: Can change until handler starts work
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: How Many Recent Requests to Keep?
questions.description: How many of a user's recent requests should be saved for quick resubmit?
questions.whyMatters: Favorites and recents make it faster to submit common requests. But too many clutter the list.
questions.example: Keep the last 10 requests for 7 days so people can quickly resubmit 'Coils for Press 5'.

questions.question: How Many Days to Keep Recent Requests?
questions.description: After how many days should old requests be removed from the recents list?

questions.question: Auto-Logout Time for Shared Kiosks (Minutes)
questions.description: How long should someone be able to sit idle on a shared floor kiosk before auto-logout?
questions.whyMatters: Short timeouts are more secure but might annoy people. Long timeouts are convenient but risky on shared computers.
questions.example: A kiosk on the floor might log out after 5 minutes to prevent the next person from seeing someone else's stuff.

questions.question: Auto-Logout Time for Office PCs (Minutes)
questions.description: How long can office users (Leads, Managers) sit idle before auto-logout?

questions.question: What Are the Top Daily Metrics? (Pick Top 5)
questions.description: Which numbers matter most day-to-day for monitoring performance?
questions.whyMatters: Focusing on key metrics drives the right behavior. Too many overwhelms people.
questions.example: Top 5: Wait time, SLA breaches, backlog by category, handler utilization, cancellation rate. Show these on the Lead dashboard.
options: Average wait time (request to handler acceptance)
Handler utilization (% of time on tasks)
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: Overall Priority of This Feature
questions.description: On a scale of 1-5 stars, how important is this questionnaire topic to your daily work?

questions.question: How Should the App Notify Users? (Visual Only - Plant is Too Loud for Sound)
questions.description: Select all notification methods that make sense. Remember: NO audio notifications possible.
questions.note: Plant environment is very loud - all notifications MUST be visual.

options.label: Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: Digital Forklift Safety Inspection
questions.description: Currently, forklift safety inspections are done on paper once per shift. Should the app handle this digitally?
questions.whyMatters: Digitizing the inspection saves time, ensures compliance, and allows the app to prompt Material Handlers who haven't completed their shift inspection yet. The system could track which forklift was inspected and print a record if needed.
questions.example: When a Material Handler logs in and selects their forklift, the app checks if that forklift's inspection is done for the current shift. If not, it prompts them to complete it before continuing. Inspection can be printed or stored digitally.
questions.note: This would replace handwritten forklift safety inspection sheets and integrate compliance tracking into the daily workflow.
options: Yes - but still need to print inspection sheet
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: How Often Should Forklift Inspections Be Required?
questions.description: Current practice is once per shift. Should this continue or change?
questions.whyMatters: Frequency affects safety compliance and operational flow. Too frequent slows work, too infrequent risks safety violations.
questions.example: Once per shift means each forklift is inspected before use on 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and Weekend shifts. Per-use means every operator inspects before driving.
options: Once per forklift per day (any shift)
Before each use by each operator
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: When Should the App Prompt for Forklift Inspection?
questions.description: If a Material Handler is using a forklift that hasn't been inspected, when should they be prompted?
questions.whyMatters: Timing affects whether the inspection is a blocker or a reminder. Blocking prevents work until complete, reminders allow deferral.
questions.example: On login with forklift selection blocks access until inspection is done. Before creating first task allows them to inspect when ready.
options: Only if supervisor hasn't approved bypass
Does not matter for my Department

questions.question: Completion Date
questions.description: When are you filling this out?

questions.question: What Works with tablesready.com?
questions.description: List the things that work well now that we should keep in the new system.
questions.placeholder: Example: Easy to submit requests, can see task status, etc.

questions.question: What Doesn't Work with tablesready.com?
questions.description: List the pain points, frustrations, or missing features.
questions.placeholder: Example: Too many clicks, can't see who's working on my request, etc.

questions.question: Must-Have Features
questions.description: What features are absolutely critical for the new system to have?
